meeting_annotations.transcript: So I think we can get started. Welcome everyone to the meeting today. I'm Lingyin, and I'm going to be the facilitator for today's discussion. meeting_annotations.speaker: Jin Zhang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone, I'm Jin. I'm a PhD student at UCSD. I'm working on self-supervised learning for natural language processing. I'm excited to be here and share my thoughts on this topic.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: A document with the title 'Self-Supervised Learning' is being shared.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jin Zhang
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I think self-supervised learning is a very promising approach for improving the performance of our models. It allows us to train models on large amounts of unlabeled data, which is very useful in many real-world applications.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: A document with the title 'Self-Supervised Learning' is being shared.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jin Zhang
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think one of the biggest challenges in self-supervised learning is how to design the pretext task. The pretext task is the task that we use to train the model on unlabeled data. It's important to choose a pretext task that is relevant to the downstream task that we want to solve.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: A document with the title 'Self-Supervised Learning' is being shared.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jin Zhang
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think another challenge is how to evaluate the performance of self-supervised learning models. It's not always clear how to measure the quality of the representations that the model learns. We need to develop new evaluation metrics that can capture the relevant aspects of the representations.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: A document with the title 'Self-Supervised Learning' is being shared.
